snippet.textDisplay: For me the game that made the greatest impact on me was Warcraft III: ROC & TFT. During the golden age of custom game development. When DOTA was in its infancy and people expressed their creativity through the world editor. I made my own custom game and the process of it all was what inspired me to be a computer programmer. It was the birthplace of my love of computer logic. I would literally be online for 24+ hours playing custom games and chatting online and being a part of a clan and the whole community before everything turned to shit with the bots hosting more games than there were people online. If you try to play now, there are only a handful of custom games that get any attention, whereas my downloads folder in the golden era had literally hundreds of custom games and each one saw some play from time to time. I would kill to go back in time and do it all again.

snippet.textDisplay: Pokémon Diamond version. My parents wouldn't let me own any video games until I turned 10, and my first real game was on the DS. (Gameboy was no longer in stores) Although I will admit I enjoyed Alpha Sapphire much more, Diamond had a lot of influence over me. I just remember getting so attached to my Pokémon and getting so fired up for battles! I never fully completed it, though, as I sucked at the Elite Four. Still remember it, though...I even got the event Celebi, but like the simple child I was, I gave the game away without transporting the Celebi to another game...(sigh)

snippet.textDisplay:
When I played my first video game (Super Mario Bros for NES) I was about 5 or 6 and my mind was BLOWN!!! I thought it all looked so real and I had full control! It was incredible! Needless to say I have these great memories about how real so many games looked (Mega Man, TMNT, Zelda, Sonic, Pirates, Street Fighter). I grew up as the graphics got better, but I swear my imagination filled in all the missing pixels for those old games in a way that no new console can do.

THAT SAID: The first time I ever got stoned I went to Fred Meyer and they had the NEW Mario 64. First time ever playing a real 3D game! First time being stoned! It melts my mind just talking about it. When I finally got my hands on my very own N64 I beat through that sucker twice in a row (all 120 stars!) without hesitation.

Thanks for posting and giving me a chance to reminisce!

What a beatiful souvenir! Well Mario 64 had a impact on me (as for a lot of people), but let me think, there was a lot of games that impact me in diferent ways but I will say a game that made me a very fan and enjoy every chapter or saga: Super Robot Taisen 4 (SNES). Why this game? Since Kid I loved Robots, Mazinger Z was my favorite show and when I found that there was a game who appears not only him but a lot of other super robots I was fond of... In that time my mind was fascinating to discover who where the other robots, their pilots, their histoy. Today I have a great culture of this kind of genre. For me each time I play a Supor Robot Taisen I enjoy in a special and personal way, it's very dificult to explain it in a few sentences...
Well in resume, there was a lot of game that impact me but that make that I enter in a unknown world of super robot as he did Super Robot Taisen 4... it's unique.

snippet.textDisplay: When I was 14 I saw what I thought was a very goofy name for a video game:  Final Fantasy 7.  I thought 'wtf, FINAL fantasy...7?  The cover art doesn't explain anything, nor does watching the title screen.  I went in totally blind, immersing myself in what I found to be the greatest game I have ever played.  I decided to devote a significant portion of my life to this game.  And so I have.  It changed me into who I am today, no kidding.  I only remember the masive electric eel from Mario64.

snippet.textDisplay: Okay, since you asked there are two games I've had good memories of, same genra but not for the same reason. Freshman year in highschool I played the original Call of Duty, and I remember that breathless feeling I got when I slogged through the final level as the Russians and got to Reichstag. Felt awesome. Then the scene with Andrew Ryan in Bioshock four years later. I still hear the words "a man chooses, a slave obeys" in my head clear as day when I go to school.

My favourite game and the one which had the biggest impact on me was Chrono Cross (Playstation). An excellent story, amazing graphics (with well-proportioned characters), absolutely wonderful music, ended in 45 hours. Just one/my favourite game. I played it when I was 15, that was only two years ago. 
I remember that one day, I was playing Chrono Cross for such a moment that I forgot to go and take my sister at school. Aw.

snippet.textDisplay:
two games, Earthbound, and Ocarina of Time. Earthbound was one of the first RPGs i've ever played, at the time, i'd never seen a game quite so big in size. The game made me laugh, think, hum along with the music; it made me sad, and even terrified me at times.

OoT was the BIGGEST leap forward in gaming technology i had ever dreamed of. The first time i played it was at Blockbuster, i spent about 25 minutes just wandering around Kokiri forest, i've never had a game amaze me quite like OoT did.

snippet.textDisplay: The game that had the biggest impact on my childhood were Super Mario World, Super Metroid, Donkey Kong Country (I and II), Super Mario 64, Goldeneye 64, and Zelda 64:Ocarina of Time. It wasn't so much the gameplay as much as it was the music. When I hear the music of all those games, I remember back in my life when I was playing those games and all the fun memories I had. Now, the only game that has done that for me on the newer systems is Oblivion. Everything else is just "meh."

The game with the most memories for me would Paper Mario for the 64. [:

snippet.textDisplay:
There's so much game I loved, so it's hard to choose... But, I remember one "click" that happened in my head, was when I saw a friend of my brother bring his SNES with some RPGs to my house.
I was just watching them play all day and was like "aawwww I wanna play this!".

Can't remember the exact RPG...
I know there was Illusion of Gaia, that's the only one I remember... Let's just say, this got me hook on RPG for a looong time after (and still today)!

Besides that, I would say... Contra!

snippet.textDisplay: Legend Of Zelda: A Link To The Past. It really got me involved in the game. I was only young when I played it, so I never completed it on the SNES, but I have more recently. It defined my childhood, but there was something about it that made me want to complete it. The boss battles are some of the most creative and memorable to date. Gets my vote :)

It defined my childhood, but there was something about it that made me want to complete it. The boss battles are some of the most creative and memorable to date. Gets my vote :)

snippet.textDisplay: Pokemon Gold... I remember all my classmates running around as Charmander and Squirtle during recess and them trading Pokemon cards while sitting on the asphalt. I became determined to get a Pokemon game, and when I finally got my hands on Gold, I almost died. I had dreams of adventuring in the Pokemon world, and I even began drawing my own monster cards, which I still occasionally do to this day just for nostalgia. Pokemon Gold made me a gamer, period.

snippet.textDisplay:
Being born in 1990 and getting to experience the SNES era.  I'd say Super Mario World.  I played that game with my older sister so much.  It is the reason why I love video games today in the platforming area.  For different genres there are different games that impact how I feel.  

3D Platforming: Banjo Kazooie
RPG: Super Mario RPG
Action Adventure: Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time
Exploration: Super Metroid

That was a hard question to answer!

snippet.textDisplay: Chrono Trigger. The first JRPG I remember playing. Back then, I was into fighters, I was into platformers, I was into shooters, beat em ups and GTA. 2. But seeing a game where you take turns hitting each other seemed strange. The only thing that drew me in was the fact that the main character looked like Goku. But then the music, the story, the gameplay, the graphics were superb, and other things that would give it the title of best RPG ever. It rocked. Now if Chrono Break would just come out!!
snippet.textOriginal: Chrono Trigger. The first JRPG I remember playing. Back then, I was into fighters, I was into platformers, I was into shooters, beat em ups and GTA. 2. snippet.textDisplay:
Final Fantasy 4 (2 to those of us who played it back then) really demonstrated to me how a video game can actually tell a story; how the journey can be as satisfying as the destination, how simple pixels and some text can become living, breathing people with personalities. 

There are definitely better games out, now; but for me, Final Fantasy 4 changed the way I perceived video games, making them more like an interactive novel than a best score rank-board.

snippet.textDisplay:
The biggest impact: Final Fantasy VII, and I don't say that lightly.

But I played this game preceding that, and lemme tell you, I don't hold its presence in my heart lightly either. 

Those were the golden days. Back then, 3-D was a lively promise and a striding innovation. That has since died down. There is hardly a way to improve games now. Originality has faded so much.

The game that had the most influence on me as a kid was Metal Gear Solid. It opened my eyes to the realization that video games really were a form of storytelling, that through the medium of interactivity they could provide something unique to a story that no other form of media could.

And as this list of VGMs has shown us, it is often through the game's music that its story is best told.

snippet.textDisplay:
these are supposed to be replies to myself, but youtube sucks at doing that.

- super smash bros melee. this is not even a game to me anymore. i play it "competitively" so it's bigger than that, and more of a social thing. i've made many good friends through this game, traveled to different countries (well, from canada to the US), and just gotten so much more out of it than the creators could have hoped for. i don't know what they did to make this game so intensely fun, but i thank them.

snippet.textDisplay: Super Metroid probably had the biggest impact on me, in that it was one huge inter-connected world, and it was set up that I was free to explore it in any way I wanted. Never before had a game felt so expansive. The music and graphics made an atmospheric experience I had never felt before too. Also, Lunar: Silver Star Story was the first game to really get me interested in the story and characters. I had played RPGs before, but they never made me feel they had real emotion in their script.

snippet.textDisplay:
Incidentally, my dad is also the reason i played secret of evermore =) i glanced at it on a shelf one day, but didn't pick it up; he thought it looked interesting, and upon looking at the case more closely (this was a small store without the actual box art) i agreed.

- super mario rpg. one time i broke both my wrists, and among my first thoughts was "I hope I can still play super mario rpg." turns out i could, it just hurt a bunch. this is another near flawless game.

snippet.textDisplay:
some of the more important games to me:

- ff7. this is the deepest game i've ever played. i played it again recently, and though i can see its flaws more easily now, it still gets to me on a level most video games don't; usually that place is reserved for movies and music.

- super metroid. this game is perfect. it is highly atmospheric. it's also the only game my dad has ever helped me get past a puzzle on. now, maybe 10 years later, i can beat it in under an hour.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel the same way about SM64.  The first console I had was a NES but the first game that truly had an impact on me was Goldeneye 64.  I loved other games before it but Goldeneye was the first multiplayer game in my memory that all of my friends and myself would play nonstop all weekend and have great fun destroying each other on.  Never got old.  Nine years later and we still play from time to time when everyone is in town.  Top 2 players play on, bottom 2 surrender controllers, rinse/repeat.

snippet.textDisplay:
nice choice!

Anyway, the game that had the biggest impact on me? Hmm....either this or Banjo-Kazooie are the ones I first got seriously into, but I'd have to either say the original Doom, or Ocarina of Time. Those introduced me to how "complex" video gaming has become, and how more "complex" it will continue to be. Congrats on 400!

snippet.textDisplay: It might sound cliche but Final Fantasy 7 has that distinction with me.  I remember when it came out how bad I wanted it, but didn't have a Playstation.  I played it my cousins, but that would be for a short time.  Then that Christmas I opened a gift I got FF7... then continuted to open until I got the Playstation, haha.  That game was my winter break.
